nodes.description: Zarqawi's father died in 1984, leading him to drop out of school and engage in a life of drinking, drug abuse, and violence.
nodes.support_text: Zarqawi's father, a local tribal leader and retired army officer, died in 1984, leaving his mother a small pension to raise six daughters and four sons. Devastated by the death of his father, the seventeen-year-old adolescent dropped out of school and descended into a life of drinking, drug abuse, and violence on the streets of Zarqa.

nodes.description: Zarqawi was jailed for drug possession and sexual assault, which exposed him to radical Salafist preachers in a Palestinian refugee camp in Zarqa.
nodes.support_text: He soon ran afoul of the authorities and was jailed for drug possession and sexual assault. Ironically, it was probably his criminal activities that first drew him into the city's abject and lawless Palestinian refugee camp, where he was exposed to radical Salafist preachers.

nodes.description: Zarqawi married one of his maternal cousins and acquired a clerical job in the local municipality before leaving for Afghanistan in 1989.
nodes.support_text: After acquiring a clerical job in the local municipality, he married one of his maternal cousins. In 1989, however, Zarqawi abruptly left his family to go to Afghanistan.

nodes.description: Zarqawi went to Afghanistan hoping to witness the establishment of the world's first Sunni Islamist state but found the Mujahideen front fragmented.
nodes.support_text: By this time, Soviet troops had already pulled out of the country  evidently he was expecting to join a triumphant march on Kabul and witness the establishment of the world's first Sunni Islamist state. Instead, he saw the Mujahideen front fragment along tribal and ethnic lines, unable to deliver the coup de grace to the 'godless' Soviet-installed regime in Kabul for three years.

nodes.description: From 1991, Zarqawi spent most of his time in Peshawar, Pakistan, where he came under the influence of Muhammad al-Ma...
nodes.support_text: From 1991, he was spending most of his time in Peshawar, Pakistan  once a way station for Arab volunteers going to Afghanistan, now teeming with disillusioned Arab fighters debating what to do next. It is here that Zarqawi came under the influence of Muhammad al-Ma...

nodes.description: 他主要作为一家激进伊斯兰主义杂志的记者工作
nodes.support_text: 他主要作为一家激进伊斯兰主义杂志的记者工作

edges.support_text: Zarqawi's father, a local tribal leader and retired army officer, died in 1984, leaving his mother a small pension to raise six daughters and four sons. Devastated by the death of his father, the seventeen-year-old adolescent dropped out of school and descended into a life of drinking, drug abuse, and violence on the streets of Zarqa.

He soon ran afoul of the authorities and was jailed for drug possession and sexual assault. Ironically, it was probably his criminal activities that first drew him into the city's abject and lawless Palestinian refugee camp, where he was exposed to radical Salafist preachers.
After acquiring a clerical job in the local municipality, he married one of his maternal cousins. In 1989, however, Zarqawi abruptly left his family to go to Afghanistan.

By this time, Soviet troops had already pulled out of the country  evidently he was expecting to join a triumphant march on Kabul and witness the establishment of the world's first Sunni Islamist state. Instead, he saw the Mujahideen front fragment along tribal and ethnic lines, unable to deliver the coup de grace to the 'godless' Soviet-installed regime in Kabul for three years.
扎卡维制定了看似有效的恐怖主义战略的轮廓，随后该战略破坏了伊拉克战后政治过渡
他主要作为一家激进伊斯兰主义杂志的记者工作，之后前往白沙瓦
